heading: making sense of computers
subheading: all this crashing and rebooting -- your computer just doesn't understand you. but someday it will. megan watzke reports from cambridge, massachusetts.
author: megan watzke
text: cambridge, massachusetts -- most computer users blame themselves for the lack of communication with their machines, but it's really not their fault. computers have never been designed to perform in ways that humans require. the sens*bles conference on wednesday, sponsored by mit's media lab, explored the ways that researchers in both academia and industry are trying to change that."so far we've tried to make people conform to the machines, and i think that's wrong," said walter mossberg, technology columnist for the wall street journal and emcee of the conference. "i hate to hear the term 'computer literate,' because i think we should be making machines that are 'human literate.'"to that end, computers will need to become not only traditionally intelligent, such as having the ability to do calculus problems, but also they will need to learn emotional intelligence."computers are no good because they have no common sense," said marvin minsky, a professor at the mit media lab. "it's much easier to make a computer chess player than a computer housekeeper, since the housekeeper knows what you like and don't like."according to nicholas negroponte, also of the media lab, two major trends in computing are making computers into forms other than the traditional keyboard-mouse combination and developing computers that feel emotions and understand the user."think back to your favorite teacher when you were growing up," said negroponte. "you liked them not because they knew their subject better, but because they knew you better. that's what it should be like with computers."while many of the ideas at the sens*bles conference are at least 5 to 10 years away, some solutions are probably closer at hand. for example, media lab researchers are working with a squeeze-mouse, a modified mouse that conveys the user's emotional intensity by the amount of pressure placed on sensors. computers are also being developed that would be sensitive to moods and feelings from voice patterns, pitch, volume, and vocabulary data.jack brees, assistant director of research and development at microsoft, admitted that the computer industry has a long way to go before their machines are truly "user friendly.""our biggest challenge now is how to get computers to react and adapt to the user," said brees, who unveiled a prototype desktop agent that would modify its messages to the user (including its tone of voice and word choices) based on the user's mood.members of the media lab also handed out a working example of a sensing computer to each audience member. the "galvactivator" is a glove-like device the media lab developed, which can detect a person's skin conductivity by measuring the changes in electric pulses in the palm."the galvactivator does not sense your emotions," said jocelyn scheirer, research associate at the media lab, "however, it does sense 'arousal,' one component of emotion."as a test of arousal -- or, intensity -- of emotion, scheirer instructed the audience to blow up balloons until they popped. indeed, as the noise of the popping plastic increased, the led monitors on each galvactivator lit up, until kresge auditorium was illuminated by hundreds of glowing red lights.of course, leds on gloves do not necessarily make for an improved relationship between human and machine. thus, said byron reeves, stanford university professor, his lab is working on a way to process that information once a computer can, indeed, detect emotions."we've really stolen many of our ideas from psychology and sociology," said reeves. "while those disciplines have looked only at human-human interactions, i think they can go a long way in helping with the human-computer interface."and, until computer builders and designers get that ironed out, remember, it's still not your fault.
